title: How to Reduce Your Plastic Usage in Your Bathroom Routine

steps.headline: Assess your bathroom habits.
steps.description: Not everyone follows the same steps in their bathroom routine. Some people may use more products in general and will take longer to switch to new plastic-free products. You must take a look at what plastic products you use in your everyday routine. This allows for you to fully understand what can be replaced with better environmentally-friendly options.

steps.headline: Give yourself some time.
steps.description: Changing how you live can be a daunting task. Give yourself time to completely go plastic free. Start in small, accomplishable steps. Changing your bathroom routine is a great way to make the small steps necessary to change other areas where you use plastic in your life. If you change everything about what you do, you will be more likely to not commit to the changes.

steps.headline: Reduce, reuse, and recycle whenever possible.
steps.description: Stop using unnecessary products in your routine. You know what you normally use as opposed to what you actually need. Plastic bottles that you have already used once rinsed out and dried are great storage containers for other products and allow for that bottle to have another use. Reusing towels after more than one shower allows for you to use less water when doing laundry. Whatever you cannot reuse try to recycle instead of throwing it away.

steps.headline: Stop using plastic shampoo and conditioner bottles.
steps.description: Plastic shampoo and conditioner bottles can be replaced so that your hair still feels clean and full of volume. One popular option is to switch to shampoo bars. These bars are simple to use; just rub over your hair and lather that scalp! There are also options for conditioner bars as well as combo shampoo and conditioner bars. These bars also come in a wide variety for all hair types. Some stores also carry bulk shampoo and conditioner where you can bring your own containers. This is harder to find, but takes less getting used to than bar shampoo.

steps.headline: Wash your body with old-fashioned soap.
steps.description: Bars of soap are the classic form of soap. This is one of the easiest switched to make because bar soaps are a great alternative to body washes and can be bought anywhere. There are many different scents as well as formulas for skin types. Gentle bar soap can even be used to wash your face. Natural loofahs are available, as well as washcloths, that offer a plastic-free way to wash your body with this version of soap.

steps.headline: Replace your razor.
steps.description: The EPA estimated that over 2 billion razors end up in a landfill every year. That is millions of pounds of plastic! In a single year, you could be throwing away 24 or more disposable razor heads. To have the same effect of those 24 razor heads, make the switch to an electric razor, which is a clean an effective tool for hair removal, or a safety razor. Safety razors have been around for years and are a simple way to switch to a plastic-free life. This razor stays sharp longer and with a careful, slow hand is very effective to use. Blade replacements cost far less than disposable razor heads. When done with a razor blade, simply place it in a blade bank, a device that collects old razor blades, and properly recycle the entire blade bank when it is full. This allows for safe disposal of the blades, as well as encouraging recycling.

steps.headline: Find an alternative to your shaving cream.
steps.description:
Shaving cream allows for a silky-smooth shave and is necessary to not irritate skin. There are many products out there on the market that accomplish this feat, are plastic-free, and may be dual-propose. When using these products, make sure to lather the product before shaving. Alternatives to shaving cream include:
Coconut oil
Jojoba oil
Shampoo bar
Shaving bar
Bar soap

steps.headline: Buy package-free deodorant.
steps.description: Sticks and bars of deodorant can be bought from many stores and online retailers. They work just like other deodorants, by rubbing the product on your skin in the needed areas. It is important to keep the stick in an airtight container to keep it fresh for longer. If you are feeling more adventurous you can also try deodorant stones. These stones use the mineral salt potassium alum to prevent odor-causing bacteria. This means that you will still sweat, but the sweat will not stink.

steps.headline: Replace your toothbrush.
steps.description: Bamboo or wooden toothbrushes are great alternatives to plastic toothbrushes. The bristles on this type of brush last as long as regular ones do and dentist recommend that you replace your toothbrush every 3 months. Because of this, you can save up to four plastic toothbrushes from being thrown away every year! They still allow for a great clean, but will naturally decompose when thrown away unlike a plastic brush. They can be bought in many retail stores or online.

steps.headline: Make your own toothpaste.
steps.description:
The easiest way to reducing plastic tube of toothpaste is to make your own. There are other zero waste alternatives to toothpaste, but these products may also contain a large amount of plastic. But never fear! Making toothpaste is simple and will you will never have to deal with how to get that frustrating last drop out of the tube. To make you will need:
Mix 3 tablespoons coconut oil, 1 1/2 tablespoons baking soda, and 25-30 drops food-grade peppermint essential oil in a glass jar. Add more coconut oil or peppermint oil to your taste as needed. You can now simply leave your glass jar covered in your bathroom and scope some on your toothbrush whenever you need it.

steps.headline: Make your own mouthwash.
steps.description:
With a very simple recipe, you can make a mouthwash that leaves your mouth feeling minty fresh. Mouthwash helps us keep our mouths clean, but may type of mouthwash are made with alcohol and dyes as well as come in thick plastic containers. To make your own mouthwash simply:
Mix 1/4 cup of aloe vera juice, 1 cup of distilled water, 2 teaspoons of xylitol (can be bought in bulk), and 2 teaspoons of baking soda in a bowl. Strain it through a fine-mesh sieve. Add a few drops of peppermint essential oil. Make sure to shake well before using and don’t swallow. Store in a glass container and enjoy the clean.

steps.headline: Find alternatives for regular floss.
steps.description: Floss is a great tool for getting food left over from between teeth. Yet, it is possible to achieve this effect without the use of plastic. One great alternative is an electronic WaterPik. This tool can be up to 26% better than flossing with regular floss and simply works by holding the tip of the product between your teeth and water pushing food matter out from between your teeth. If you want the traditional feel of dental floss, there is a form of plastic-free dental floss made from silk and beeswax. This form of floss comes in a small glass jar and you can easily purchase refills online.
